items.title: Federal Court Rules Trump Administration’s “Gender Ideology” Ban on Art Endowments Unconstitutional
items.excerpt: National Endowment for the Arts (NEA) grants are not required to comply with President Trump’s executive order on “gender ideology” , a Rhode Island federal court ruled on Friday, per the New York Times . The court determined that the new policy, which would have been in effec…

items.title: The most powerful weapon in a freelancer's toolkit isn't talent. It's communication
items.excerpt: Clear, consistent communication is the quiet superpower of every successful freelancer. It builds trust, keeps projects on track and turns one-off jobs into relationships that last for years. Ignore it, and even the best work won't save you.

items.title: Stéphanie Kilgast’s Book ‘Utopia’ Chronicles Ten Years of Vibrant, Post-Apocalyptic Sculptures
items.excerpt: In Stéphanie Kilgast ’s vibrant yet poignant pieces, a speculative future without humans gives rise to unusual relationships. “In my artwork, humanity is absent, leaving behind its legacy of objects, buildings, and trash,” the artist says. She continues:

items.title: ‘Sixties Surreal’ Curator Dan Nadel Is Expanding American Art History, One Outlier at a Time
items.excerpt: “I like the strong personal visionary stuff that generally doesn’t fit in the mainstream,” the artist Robert Crumb once wrote in a letter to the cartoonist B. N. Duncan. Dan Nadel quotes that letter in Crumb , his recent biography of the artist , but it’s a statement that may …

items.title: Shape the Future of Art, Design, and Architecture at Cranbrook Academy of Art
items.excerpt: Cranbrook Academy of Art is not just a graduate school—it’s a dynamic community of architects, artists, and designers redefining visual and material culture. Known for decades as the “incubator of mid-century modernism,” Cranbrook has been at the forefront of innovation for ne…

items.title: Rare Gold Coin, Buried for 50 Years, Could Command $2.5 Million at Auction
items.excerpt: The most expensive coin collection ever assembled numbers 15,000 coins—it’s so large and historically thorough that it’s being sold in a series of 15 auctions set to spread out over three years. Besides being so valuable, it also has the distinction of having been buried for 5…

items.title: Illustrated thinking: Why brands are turning back to drawing
items.excerpt: From murals to motion, illustration is starting to reassert itself in advertising, but when do agencies and brands choose to commission it, and when do they shy away? We asked creatives, art buyers, agents and illustrators to weigh in.

items.title: Frieze Sculpture Unleashes a Provocative Play of Light and Shadow—See 5 Standouts

items.title: Cultural Narratives and Craft Converge in the 2025 World of WearableArt Competition
items.excerpt: Wellington’s extravagant World of WearableArt is back for 2025, including pieces by 85 finalists that showcase today’s most elaborate and fanciful costumes . One hundred designers from 17 countries competed for a prize pool of more than $200,000 New Zealand dollars across 25 a…

items.title: Crafted Without Compromise: Deuce Studio refreshes White Rabbit Pizza Co.
items.excerpt: It's fast becoming the go-to brand for gluten-free pizza, and it's just unveiled a bold new look, celebrating Italian heritage and inclusivity.

items.title: Contemporary Art Finds a Home in New York’s Most Iconic Cathedral
items.excerpt: For generations, St. Patrick’s Cathedral in New York City has been known as America’s parish, a historic and architecturally stunning spiritual hub for the nation’s Catholics. But the Gothic revival church, which welcomes upwards of 10 million visitors a year, just got its lar…

items.title: ‘Companions’ Celebrates Our Animal Friends and Colleagues
items.excerpt: “Play between humans and pets, as well as simply spending time peaceably hanging out together, brings joy to all the participants. Surely that is one important meaning of companion species.” –Donna Haraway, ‘Companion Species Manifesto ‘

items.title: Collector Bernard Arnault Says France’s Wealth Tax ‘Aims to Destroy the Liberal Economy’
items.excerpt: Art collector Bernard Arnault , one of the richest men in the world, spoke bitterly against plans for France to institute a tax on the ultra-wealthy, calling the proposal “offensive.”

items.title: Cai Guo-Qiang Under Fire for Controversial Pyrotechnic Show in Tibet
items.excerpt: A fireworks show staged by Chinese artist Cai Guo-Qiang at the base of the Himalayas in Tibet has led to stinging criticism online. Amid the outcry, both the artist and Arc’teryx, the outdoor apparel brand that sponsored the project, issued apologies.

items.title: Artist Bettina Pousttchi Pushes Photography to Its Limit in a Berlin Show
items.excerpt: Photography has undergone numerous evolutions since its invention, and German artist Bettina Pousttchi is broadening what the medium can be even further.

items.title: Art Organizations Prevail in Legal Battle Over NEA Grants
The Full U.S. Constitution Is on Display for the First Time Ever
items.excerpt: The complete U.S. Constitution has gone on display for the first time in history.

items.title: From Paris to Vegas: How the Core Art Gallery Is Raising the Stakes
items.excerpt: The landscape of art collecting is constantly shifting, with today’s collectors craving not only works they connect with but experiences that feel immersive and unforgettable. The Core Art Gallery has stepped squarely into that space, pioneering inventive ways to present art a…

items.excerpt: Time released its annual Time 100 list on Friday, featuring the magazine’s picks for the most influential people of the year, divided into six categories: artists, innovators, titans, icons, leaders, and pioneers. Four art world figures made it onto this year’s list: visual ar…

items.title: Sunken Treasures Salvaged From Titanic’s Ill-Fated Sister Ship
items.excerpt: The first batch of artifacts has been retrieved from the bottom of the Aegean Sea, where the Britannic , the sister ship of the Titanic , has lain for more than a century.

items.title: Painting and Sculpture Converge in Dual Solo Shows at Alfonso Artiaco
items.excerpt: At Alfonso Artiaco in Naples, two artists with two distinct visions—one working primarily in sculpture, the other painting—delicately tap into the nature of color, form, and viewer experience, resulting in a cross-medium dialogue that illustrates the vast landscape of artmakin…

items.title: Why Possible's optical illusion for the VMAs set a new standard in spatial design
items.excerpt: The first time I witnessed an anamorphic display that truly worked was just over a year ago. Late at night, I was at a crossroads in Shinjuku, Tokyo, watching what appeared to be a giant cat leap straight out of a digital billboard, and seriously wondered if someone had slippe…

items.title: Think like a mustache: how illustrator Tanakan Bangnoi finds the joy in everyday life
items.excerpt: The story of Thai illustrator Tanakan Bangnoi demonstrates how creative careers rarely run smoothly, but resilience and a positive outlook can help turn things around.

items.title: How two creatives captured a life of wisdom in one beautiful short
items.excerpt: Santiago Carrasquilla and Danaé Gosset travelled to Argentina with just a camera and captured something quite extraordinary in the life and work of sign painter Luis Benz.

items.title: Smash takes down WeTransfer in this cheeky but clever campaign
items.excerpt: The rival file-sharing service harnesses humour brilliantly to capitalise on the WeTransfer AI training controversy and lure in creative professionals.

items.title: Expert tips on getting into creative flow (and staying there)
items.excerpt: Finding focus in a fractured world requires intention, ritual and perhaps a bit of creative rebellion. We canvased our community on how to maximise your creative flow, and we share their practical, achievable tips below.

items.title: Bukhara's Big Debut: A Silk Road city reawakens with contemporary art
items.excerpt: The ancient Uzbekistan city on the Silk Road swaps centuries of civilisation and traditional trade for an exuberant international contemporary art fest.

items.title: Beyond the Beaches: Helin Bereket captures the solitude of Australia's forgotten towns
items.excerpt: The Berlin-based photographer documents the haunting beauty of rural decline in her latest series, which explores abandoned spaces.

items.title: Sara Maese is creating an entire universe out of simple forms and lovely warm colours
items.excerpt: "I have a good eye for colour and usually go with my gut," says this inspiring young illustrator from southern Spain.

items.title: Otherway rebrands Robin AI with a warm, tactile identity that flips the legal tech narrative
items.excerpt: Legal AI platform Robin has unveiled a new identity by London studio Otherway. The rebrand positions law not as a blocker but a business enabler, with a visual world rooted in optimism, tactility, and humanity.

items.title: Gab at 40: Why Glasgow's much-loved creative gathering still has its spark
items.excerpt: The ever-popular event in Scotland has just marked a milestone. Creative Boom headed north to find out why everyone keeps raving about Gab.

items.title: Fee Greening brings her magic touch to Briggs's Dictionary of Fairies
items.excerpt: One of the most important tomes of British folklore is being republished – with inspiring imagery by fairy expert Fee Greening.

items.title: Family & Friends and Mornflake launch a free-spirited snack brand
items.excerpt: Yup! – a new range of "Anytime Oat Crumbles" – reimagines the humble porridge pot as a sweet, stylish, and satisfying snack for any time of day.

items.title: Booms & Shakes: New hires, big wins, studio birthdays and more
items.excerpt: Welcome to the very first edition of Booms & Shakes – your monthly roundup of who's moving where, what agencies are winning, and the fresh ideas making noise across the creative industries.

items.title: Robot Food reimagines Co-op's Irresistible spirits and cider with storytelling and craft
items.excerpt: The Leeds studio has given Co-op's own-brand drinks range a premium makeover. Expect bespoke storytelling, tactile finishes, and a copper thread running through every bottle.

items.title: Edge Creative Studios: Building a design practice rooted in collaboration and trust
items.excerpt: From jewellery start-ups to motorsport giants, Edge Creative Studios has carved out a reputation for thoughtful, collaborative design. Founders Daniel Short and Scott Morgan reflect on their journey, the challenges of independence, and why trust and generosity sit at the heart…

items.title: Con McHugh brings On's Cloudboom Max to life with playful frame-by-frame animation
items.excerpt: Known for his rhythmic linework and playful imperfections, the Bristol-based illustrator and animator helps to turn a humble sneaker into a charming, charismatic character.

items.title: Brand Brothers reimagine Glénat's visual identity with a dynamic system rooted in heritage
items.excerpt: French publisher Glénat's new identity, created by Brand Brothers, demonstrates how studios can approach the challenge of building on an existing logo while bringing something fresh and unexpected.

items.excerpt: All images © Ricky Adam

items.title: Last mill standing: how I fell in love with James Cropper's coloured paper
items.excerpt: Britain's only working paper mill is now selling directly to designers. After spending a day there, I'd reckon that's an opportunity every creative should take advantage of.

items.title: Creatives share tricks for taming imposter syndrome that actually work
items.excerpt: From naming your inner critic to building up feel-good folders, creative professionals reveal the strategies that really work.
